step.tex: \begin{align} \text{Let }x &= \cos\theta \implies dx = -\sin\theta\cdot d\theta \\ \therefore B &= \frac{1}{2}\int\dfrac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx \\ &= -\frac{1}{2}\int\dfrac{\cos^2\theta\cdot\sin\theta}{\sqrt{1-\cos^2\theta}} d\theta \\ &= -\frac{1}{2}\int\left[\dfrac{1+\cos 2\theta}{2}\right]d\theta \\ &= -\frac{1}{4}\cdot \left[\theta + \frac{\sin 2\theta}{2}\right] + C \\ &= -\frac{1}{4}\cdot \left(\cos^{-1}x + x\cdot\sqrt{1-x^2}\right) + C \end{align}
step.reason: \text{We have used the following facts }\\ \begin{align} \sqrt{1-\cos^2\theta} &= \sin\theta \\ \cos^2\theta &= \dfrac{1+\cos 2\theta}{2} \\ \int\cos 2\theta\cdot d\theta &= \frac{\sin 2\theta}{2} \\ \frac{\sin 2\theta}{2} &= \sin\theta\cdot\cos\theta \\ \sin\theta &= \sqrt{1-\cos^2\theta} = \sqrt{1-x^2} \end{align} \\ \text{You could also have substituted }x = \sin\theta.
